biospec_descr.textblock:
-  Salivary cortisol;

        -  Blood plasma Corticotropin-releasing Hormone (CRH).

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine how difficult life-events that women experienced
      during their childhood might affect their babies.

      Women who are asked to participate in this study will fill out forms about their physical
      and mental health, have 3D ultrasounds of their baby's adrenal gland, have their stress
      responses measured and have their baby's development and stress responses assessed.

detailed_description.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the impact of maternal psychosocial stress and
      physiologic arousal on fetal adrenal gland volume across pregnancy. Maternal stress may have
      an adverse impact on the developing fetus by causing abnormal programming of the fetal
      Hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis which could lead to medical and behavioral health
      problems later in life. Non-invasive measurements of fetal adrenal gland volume by 3-D
      ultrasound may allow us to understand if maternal stress can impact fetal adrenal gland
      size. In addition, the investigators can begin to discern whether fetal adrenal size has
      behavioral ramifications for the offspring through assessment of the infants HPA axis
      response to novelty. This study presents a non-invasive, novel approach to understanding the
      impact of maternal stress on fetal and infant developments.

study_pop.textblock:
Women from the greater Philadelphia and surrounding areas who are ages 18 to 45 and
        between 8 to 17 weeks pregnant will be considered for enrollment into this study. All
        subjects must be physically healthy without a serious major medical illness as well as be
        carrying a healthy fetus. Subject will be enrolled through OB/GYN waiting room recruiting,
        fliers, advertisements and social media outlets.

facility.name: Penn Center for Women's Behavioral Wellness
Helen O. Dickens Center for Women's Health, Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania

clinical_study.official_title: Prepubertal Adversity Effect on Maternal Arousal, Preterm Birth and Infant Stress Response

primary_outcome.description: The primary outcome variable is fetal adrenal size as measured by volume (ml) between 20 weeks and 22 weeks gestational age.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: The secondary outcomes are physiologic arousal based on the maternal response to the acoustic startle paradigm or TSST plus salivary cortisol at 15-17 weeks gestational age and 6-8 weeks postpartum.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 15 to 21 weeks gestational age and 6 to 8 weeks postpartum

secondary_outcome.description: The secondary outcomes are physiologic arousal based on infant stress responses as measured by the infant behavioral assessment and salivary cortisol at 6 months postpartum.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
